content: How can I help you today?

I've just been so stressed lately, especially with work. I can't seem to get any sleep because my mind just won't stop racing at night. I guess I'm here because my partner thought it might help, but I'm not sure what to expect.

That sounds really overwhelming—trying to handle stress from work while struggling with sleep and a restless mind is a lot to carry. It says a lot about you that you're open to exploring something that might help, even if you're unsure what to expect. What do you think might make a difference for you right now, even in small ways?

Honestly, I have no idea. I just feel stuck. Every time I try to relax, my thoughts spiral, and it's hard to even imagine what would help. Maybe if I could stop overthinking at night, that would be something, but I don’t even know where to start with that.

Feeling stuck can be really tough—it can make even the smallest steps feel impossible. But recognizing how your thoughts spiral and how it impacts you is already a meaningful insight. You mentioned wanting to stop overthinking at night. What do you think makes unwinding at the end of the day so challenging?

It’s like my brain just won’t shut off, you know? I keep replaying my day, worrying about mistakes I might’ve made, and imagining worst-case scenarios at work. I want to relax, but I feel like I have to be prepared for everything, and that keeps me from being able to just let go. And then I end up on my phone, scrolling, which I know doesn’t help…but it feels like the only thing I can do to distract myself.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of pressure to stay prepared and prevent mistakes, even at the expense of your own rest. Replaying the day and imagining worst-case scenarios can feel consuming, especially when it keeps pulling you back into work. Turning to your phone might feel like a short-term escape, but it’s also a sign you're really craving distraction from that mental overload. What would it mean to you to let go of some of those worries, even just a little, at night?

I think it would mean a lot, honestly. It feels like such a huge weight to always be "on," even when I just want to rest. But the idea of letting go scares me too—like if I stop worrying, I'll mess something up or won’t see something coming. I just don't know how to feel okay with that.

It makes sense why letting go feels scary—it seems like worrying has become almost a way to protect yourself, like staying vigilant might somehow prevent mistakes or surprises. But at the same time, carrying that weight constantly sounds exhausting, and you're wishing for relief. What would it take for you to feel safe enough to ease up, even in small ways, without feeling like you're losing your grip on things?

It might help for me to have something I can trust to keep things in control, like writing things down or having a plan for the next day that I can look at if I need to. But even then, I’m not sure I’d be able to turn my brain off. It just feels like there’s always something I could miss.

Having a plan or writing things down sounds like it could provide a sense of structure and control that might help ease the constant pressure you're under. It’s understandable that the fear of missing something still lingers, though, even with tools like that. Do you think it would make a difference to explore ways of balancing staying prepared while also giving yourself permission to rest?

Maybe, but I don’t really know how to find that balance. It feels like if I try to rest, I’m being irresponsible or setting myself up to fail. I guess part of me knows I need rest to function better, but it doesn’t stop that guilt or worry from creeping in.

It sounds like part of you really understands how important rest is for functioning your best, but there’s another part of you that connects resting with guilt, like it might mean you're neglecting your responsibilities. That kind of inner conflict can be really draining, especially when both sides pull at you. What do you think could help you start giving yourself permission to rest without feeling like you're letting your guard down?

Maybe if I could remind myself that resting is actually part of being responsible—like, I can't do my best at work or for my family if I'm completely burnt out. But I think it’s going to take some time to really believe that, especially when the worries feel so loud.

That’s an important perspective—recognizing that rest itself is a key part of being responsible and showing up fully for the things that matter to you. It’s no small shift to quiet those loud worries, but even starting to remind yourself of that connection between rest and being at your best could make a difference over time. What’s one small step you’d feel comfortable trying to work toward this balance?

Maybe I could start by putting my phone away at a certain time at night and writing down my worries instead, so they’re out of my head. It feels a bit uncomfortable, but I think it could help me stop adding more stress by scrolling. I’m not sure I’d stick to it, though—part of me feels like I’d fall back into the habit.

That’s a thoughtful step—putting your phone aside and writing down your worries sounds like a way to give yourself space to unwind while feeling like you're still addressing what's on your mind. It's natural to feel unsure about sticking to it, especially with old habits in the mix. What could you do to make this feel easier or more doable for yourself?

Maybe I could set an alarm as a reminder to put my phone down, or try leaving it in another room so it’s not so easy to reach for. If I pair it with something relaxing, like listening to calming music or deep breathing while I write, it might feel less forced. I’m still not sure if I’ll be perfect with it, but it’s worth a try.

That sounds like a creative plan—using an alarm as a reminder and pairing it with something calming to make the transition feel less forced shows you're really thinking about what might work for you. Taking small, imperfect steps is okay; the effort itself is meaningful. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about before exploring how to move forward with this idea?
Actually, I think I’m good for now. Thank you for talking through this with me—it’s been helpful to think about some small changes I could try. I appreciate it.
